title: Day 1300
content:
# Day 1300

I watched _Tron: Legacy_ again tonight. Watching the newest one recently made me want to go back and watch the one I originally saw in theaters as a teenager. Man, _Tron: Legacy_ an elite film. I used to think it was a movie about computers, light bikes, and Daft Punk. Which it is, and that's part of what makes it incredible. But now, as I get older, I see it for even more. The film was a parable about perfection and how dangerous it can be.

Kevin Flynn created a digital world and a digital copy of himself, Clu, to build "the perfect system." It sounds noble, doesn't it? We all say things like that in our own ways. The perfect body. The perfect relationship. The perfect plan. But as the quote goes "man makes plans and God laughs".

Perfection is a trap. It's a moving target that gets sharper every time you chase it. Clu couldn't understand imperfection because he couldn't accept that life's beauty hides in what doesn't fit neatly. So he deleted, controlled, and optimized...literally committing digital genocide on the grid and thus destroying everything worth saving in his world.

I catch myself doing that. Dreaming about how things will be perfect one day, how I'll fix every flaw if I just have the right circumstances, the right tools, the right timing. Polish every rough edge, align every variable before I start. But that's not living at all. It's more like building a cage and calling it order.

There's a scene near the end where Flynn looks at Clu, his creation, and says, "The thing about perfection is that it's unknowable. It's impossible, but it's also right in front of us, all the time. You wouldn't know that because I didn't, when I created you. I'm sorry, Clu. I'm sorry". These lines are some damn fine script writing if I do say so myself. It's what happens when our strengths, our drive, our vision, our desire for mastery, go untempered by acceptance.

Sometimes, perfection isn't found in fixing, but in noticing. The laugh that interrupts a serious conversation. The unplanned detour that becomes the best part of the trip. The moment your kid says something so weird and honest you can't stop smiling.

Perfection should not be the goal. Presence is often way more important.

So this is just a reminder to myself: stop chasing the clean lines and start seeing the glow in the mess. Life isn't supposed to compile clean. Run `npm install`, fix what matters, ignore what doesn't, and then hit `npm run dev` anyway.

Let it crash. Let it rebuild. That's where the beauty is.

![Wonder If They Make Tron Edition Cars In Real Life. Would Be Sweet To Have A Laser Wall Generated Behind My Car Haha](https://miro.medium.com/1*EGWYYiB5MQPsjp_YTcD2pA.png)

10/12/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
